ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Visit name
Have you ever had a head injury or concussion?
Notes: 0=No; 1=Yes; -9=Not applicable or missing; -8=DON'T KNOW; -7=REFUSED; -5=Presented, not answered

ElementDescription: Did you ever get knocked out or lose consciousness as a result of a head injury?
Did you ever experience any symptoms immediately after a head injury?
Did you receive any kind of medical attention/treatment for a head injury?
Age at first head injury in years
Age at most recent head injury in years
Number of head injuries reported
Rating of most severe head injury
Notes: 1=No Head Injury; 2=Mild head injury/concussion with no loss of consciousness; 3=Mild head injury/concussion with brief loss of consciousness; 4=Mild head injury with LOC for between 2-30 minutes.... lasting 1-24 hours; 5=Mild head injury with LOC for between 2-30 minutes.... lasting 1-7 days; 6=Mild head injury with LOC for between 2-30 minutes.... lasting >7 days to 2 months; 7=Mild head injury with LOC for between 30 minutes-5 hours; 8=Head injury with LOC/coma lasting 6 hours or more

ElementDescription: Source of information
Notes: 1=Subject only; 2=Parent only; 3=Both subject and parent; -900 = Missing; -300 = N/A

ElementDescription: Site
Time Point
Traumatic Brain Injury: Guess How Long Knocked Out
Traumatic Brain Injury: Amnesia
Traumatic Brain Injury: How Much Don't Recall
Notes: 1=Just a few seconds; 2=Less than a minute; 3=One minute or more;  -8=DON'T KNOW; -7=REFUSED; -5=Presented, not answered

ElementDescription: Traumatic Brain Injury: Guess How Much Don't Recall
Traumatic Brain Injury: Sleepy/Confused/Disoriented
Traumatic Brain Injury: How Long Sleepy/Confused/Disoriented
Notes: 1=Just a few seconds; 2=Less than a minute; 3=One minute or more;  -8=DON'T KNOW; -7=REFUSED; -5=Presented, not answered

ElementDescription: Traumatic Brain Injury: Guess How Long Sleepy/Confused/Disoriented
How Long Knocked Out
Notes: 1=Just a few seconds; 2=Less than a minute; 3=One minute or more; -98=DON'T KNOW; -97=REFUSED; -8=DON'T KNOW; -7=REFUSED; -5=Presented, not answered

ElementDescription: Guess How Long Knocked Out (Unit)
Guess How Much Don't Recall (Unit)
Guess How Long Sleepy/Confused/Dis (Unit)
Trouble Knowing What Happened
Ask Same Question/Insist Could Do Things
Head Injury Indicator - Participant indicated they hit their head and also noted they have some amnesia or loss of conciousness or confused and showing positive somatic symptom indicator
Notes: 0 = No head injury with conditions; 1 = head injury with conditions

ElementDescription: Head Injury Indicator - Participant indicated they hit their head and also noted they have some amnesia or loss of conciousness or confused. (imputed measure with Freeze 1B cohort)
Notes: 0 = No head injury with conditions; 1 = head injury with conditions

ElementDescription: Fully imputed Experienced Head Injury Score using F1b Cohort
Notes: 0 = did not hit head; 1 = hit head

ElementDescription: Indicator of whether hit head
Indicate whether the participant both (a) hit their head and (b) experienced a change in mental status, such as loss of consciousness, amnesia, or reported being dazed/confused/sleepy.

6. What happened? Describe the circumstances of the injury. Probes: Seatbelt: yes/no, Airbag deployment: yes/no, sports injury, assault, fall, substance use prior, other injuries: orthopaedic, spine, body?

8. Was there any loss of memory for events immediately after the accident/impact (anterograde amnesia)? If so, how long was this period of memory loss? Probe: What happened after? 10. What kinds of symptoms did you experience immediately after this head injury? Probes: Did you have headaches?  Did your head hurt? Did bright lights or (loud) noises bother you more than usual (people talking, radio, TV)?  Did you have new/worse trouble paying attention/concentrating? Was it hard for you to remember things?  Did things look blurry or did you see double?  Did you feel grumpy or irritable?
11. How long did these symptoms last? How long did the worst symptom last? Please specify timeframe (e.g., seconds, minutes, hours, days, etc.)
12. If you received medical attention, what were the findings? Probe: Head X-Ray, CT/MRI?  EEG? Treatment for headaches/cognitive problems/mood changes? Other?

Rating of most severe head injury (exclude if > Level 6) *Note that exclusion includes history of 3 or more significant head injuries
Notes: 1 = No head injury; 2 = Mild head injury/concussion with no loss of consciousness, no confusion/post-traumatic amnesia, and brief/transient other symptoms < 15 minutes; 3 = Mild head injury/concussion with brief loss of consciousness (< 1 minute) and/or transient confusion/post-traumatic amnesia (< 5 minutes), and/or other symptoms following the injury (e.g., headache, dizziness, nausea) lasting < 1 hour; 4 = Mild head injury with LOC for between 2-30 minutes, and/or post-traumatic amnesia/confusion < 1 hour, and/or other symptoms (cognitive or behavior changes) lasting 1-24 hours; 5 = Mild head injury with LOC for between 2-30 minutes, and/or post-traumatic amnesia/confusion between 1-24 hours, and/or other symptoms (cognitive or behavior changes) lasting 1-7 days; 6 = Mild head injury with LOC for between 2-30 minutes, and/or post-traumatic amnesia/confusion between 1-24 hours, and/or other symptoms (cognitive or behavior changes) lasting > 7 days to 2 months; 7 = Head injury with LOC for 30 minutes-5 hours, and/or post-traumatic amnesia/confusion > 24 hours, and/or other symptoms lasting > 2 months.(i.e., persistent post-concussional symptoms) OR 3 or more > Level 3 head injuries; 8 = Head injury with LOC/coma lasting 6 hours or more, and/or skull fracture, and/or positive findings on head CT/MRI (e.g., bleed or other lesion); -900 = Missing; -300 = N/A
